DATATYPE.Description: A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.
A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.
A medium-size integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
An unpacked floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Behaves like a CHAR column.
This is a synonym for DECIMAL.
A date. The supported range is \a1000-01-01\a to \a9999-12-31\a.
A date and time combination. The supported range is \a1000-01-01 00:00:00\a to \a9999-12-31 23:59:59\a.
A timestamp. The range is \a1970-01-01 00:00:00\a to sometime in the year 2037. The length can be 14 (or missing), 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, or 2 representing YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, ... , YYYYMMDD, ... , YY formats.
A time. The range is \a-838:59:59\a to \a838:59:59\a.
A year in 2- or 4-digit format (default is 4-digit).

A fixed-length string (1 to 255 characters) that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. values are sorted and compared in case-insensitive fashion according to the default character set unless the BINARY keyword is given.
A variable-length string (1 to 255 characters). Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion unless the BINARY keyword is given.
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters.
An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values.
A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values.
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype

TABLE.Comments: Table: subjects. Identification includes the following variables: email, fname (first name), lname (last name), phone, passwd (password for a subject to log into the experiment web site, access personal data, and trade), comments, regdate (registration time), uid (universal ID, such as social security number). The valid bit indicates whether the status of a subject in the system. If false, we no longer use this subject for experiments.

A row in the Periods table encapsulates definition of a period. Basically, a period is an interval of time that subjects will be active - this may be limited to waiting for earnings, but usually involves trade in securities. For each period, one declares the total length in time that it lasts (time_length). A period can be set to be active after some time delay (time_delay). Unlike timeout_length in the table \Asessions\A, this delay is period-specific.

COLUMN.Comments: In milliseconds, how long the period should be open. It should be \g= to the max length of the market for each of the securities.

TABLE.Comments: This table encapsulates the securities available for a given period in a session. The following has to be specified: minimum price level (min_price), maximum price level (max_price), tick size (tick_price), a security-specific delay before opening of the markets (time_delay_s), and the length of time that exchange in the security can take place (time_length_s; obviously, time_length_s \k= time_length minus time_delay_s, where time_length is in the table \Aperiods\A). Two variables determine whether securities are linked across periods. When the end-of-period holdings of a security should be added to the initial holdings of the security with the same ID (Variable: security_id) in the subsequent period, then the Variable add_surplus should be set equal to 1; otherwise, it\as zero, in which case subjects are paid the dividend and the the securities leave the system. When end-of-period dividends are paid, two things can happen. To understand these, it\as important to distinguish between, (i) the cumulative payoffs that subjects earn across periods and which are to be converted from the experiment currency to dollars and eventually paid to subjects at the end of the session (see Table: subject_payoffs), and (ii) cash holdings that subjects can use in a period to buy securities (see Table: subject_cash_holdings). When the end-of-period payment (dividend) of a security is NOT to be added to subjects\a cumulative payoffs but instead is to be added to subjects\a cash holdings for the subsequent period, then one sets the Variable: add_dividend to 1; otherwise it is 0.\n\nThe conversion function governs how payoff for this security should be converted to actual dollar amount payoff to the subject wheras the payoff function specifies how the payoffs should be calculated for this security in the period.

COLUMN.Comments: Max unit price for the security
Min unit price for the security
Time length of availability for trading of this security
Time delay before trade in security opens, counting from beginning of period on

TABLE.Comments: Trading and payments are subject to rules to be specified in this table. These rules can be made role-specific (role_id). The most important one is the rule that determines how payoffs are computed, identified by payoff_fn_id. Entries in the column bankruptcy_cutoff determine the extent (in experiment currency) to which subjects can make promises of future payments that they may not be able to deliver on. If bankruptcy_cutoff=0, then the subject type (role_id) cannot trade to a position which obliges it to make future payments that it cannot deliver on in at least one possible future outcome. The column bankruptcy_fn_id lists the id of the function with which to determine whether the bankruptcy rule is satisfied.

Rules specific to each security and each period are specified in this table. Rules may depend on the role a subejct plays (see role_id). At this point, there are two rules to be specified: trading_rule and shortsale_constraint. 

Explanation of rules:
- trading_rule equals -1 if subject is only allowed to sell, 1 if she is only allowed to buy, 2 if she is allowed to do both, and 0 if she is not allowed to trade in the indicated period_security.
- shortsale-constraint equals number of units of period_security that can be sold without owning it. This determines the number of units of a security somebody can sell without owning any. Upon a short sale, the subject promises to 
pay the experimenter at the end of a period (and possibly future periods if security holdings are carried over - 
see add_surplus above) whatever dividend the security pays.

Top level data object. It defines experimental session which contain a number of periods, separated by some idle time (Variable: timeout_length). (Note: timeout_length differs from time_delay in the table \Aperiods\A in that it is fixed per period.) An experiment can contain one or more sessions. The experimenter can configure a session and save it as a template (is_template). When a session definition is marked as a template, it can then be used as a source to clone new session definitions. The idea here is to eventually have an admin interface from which a list of session definitions can be chosen by an experimenter.
Pricelevels for each of the security at which it can be traded.

Exchange takes place through a system referred to as open book. Subjects can submit buy (bids) or sell (asks) limit orders. Each order is for a specified number of units and a specified maximum (bid) or minimum (asks) price. Bids and asks are displayed in decreasing order of price; this list is referred to as the book. When a buy limit order specifies a maximum bid price that is at least as high as the lowest ask price in the book, then a purchase occurs: the bidder buys from the seller whose ask is the lowest (price priority) and has been in the system - at that price level - the longest (time priority). If the bidder wanted to buy more units that this seller provides, then the additional units come from other sellers in the queue at the minimum ask price. Again, time priority is adhered to (first seller in gets to sell first). If that is still not sufficient, the system checks the next available ask price level, provided that it is not above the (limit) bid price of the buyer. And so on. If part of the buy order remains unfilled when all limit sell orders below or equal to the bid price of the buyer are used up, then the buy order is posted in the book (at its bid price level). An analogous set of rules applies to sell orders.

The book is represented in the database as follows. For each security and each price level (see Table: security_pricelevels), the Table: offer_book lists the limit orders. A limit order is defined by Variable: offer_type (bid/buy or ask/sale), Variable: offer_units (number of units bought/sold), Variable: time_entry (time the order arrived in the book), Variable: offer_status (whether the order is active, canceled, or executed; when or order arrives, it is automatically active), and Variable: time_changestatus (time when the status changed from active to either canceled or executed). Transactions are recorded in the Table: transaction_book (number of units Variable: units and transaction time Variable: time_entry are recorded), which links to a Table: transaction_parties, which lists the parties (Variable: subject_id) and their role (Variable: role_id). The latter (i.e., the roles) are defined in the Table: transaction_roles (Variable: role_name).

COLUMN.Comments: Timestamp when status changes to either cancelation or accepted

TABLE.Comments: The table encapsulates subject\as holding of a particular security in a period. Note that this table should *ALWAYS* be appended instead of updated, i.e. each time the units of a security changes (i.e. when a trade occurs), a new row should be appended with a new timestamp.

The table encapsulates subject\as cash holding in a period. Note that this table should *ALWAYS* be appended instead of updated, i.e. each time the cash holding changes (i.e. a trade occurs), a new row should be appended with a new timestamp.
Lists all transactions and assigns ids to them. See Comments to table \Amarket_orders\A for further info.

The table encapsulates the parties in a transaction identified by transaction_id. It links to the offer_id, lists units_contributed (units from offer that contributed to transaction) and the role the offer played in the transaction. Offer_type=0|buy; 1|sale. Note that offers listed here are all STANDING OFFERS, as the market order that causes this transaction is listed in the market_orders table. The identity of the transacting parties can be inferred through the offer_id.

COLUMN.Comments: Indicating the role of the offer in the transaction.

TABLE.Comments: Subjects\a end-of-period payoffs are recorded in the Table: subject_payoffs (Variable: payoff). These are based on subjects\a holdings of cash and securities after all trade halts, subject to the rules specified in Table: period_functions and Variable: add_dividend in Table: period_securities. At the end of a session, subjects are eventually paid the cumulative value of the payoffs across periods (after conversion to dollars).
Cash initial for a subject with the specified role at the beginning of a period.
This table defines the inital security holdings for a subject role in a period
Assigne a role (role_id) to each subject.

Lists all \Aevents\A (orders, whether limit or market, and cancelations). Kept separate from \Aoffer_book,\A which contains strictly only the things that the market needs to see. That is, the table \Aticker_tape\A is only written and never read during trading; the \Aoffer_book\A is both written and read.
